replies.msg:
According to @talkofthecharts, this is a sticky situation because that means one of several things could be happening:

A. The D2C sales weren’t sent in, or at least not on time. Documentation indicates that noon of Friday is the deadline for D2C reporting, no exceptions.
B. The D2C sales were sent in, but in the process of vetting most were thrown out or enough fraud was discovered that the entire batch was tossed. This is unlikely as the Say So race involved a significant quantity of removals, so there is a tolerance threshold.
C. The D2C sales were sent in, but the vetting process is taking so long that it won’t be chart-ready until the public reporting day tomorrow. This is the scenario we reflected in the final prediction.

replies.msg: Life is too complicated, what’s so bad for being cliche, pitchfork

Rare compliments:

Despite all her garbled platitudes, she remains a master at executing proven chart-topping formulas. The Charlie Puth co-write “Harleys in Hawaii” is standard, breezy pop: a gently writhing beat, the word “baby” breathed over synths, vowels contorted so that “hula” rhymes with “jeweler.” “Tucked” is an understated highlight, a bass-blasted track about summoning the memory of a lover whenever she wants.


Katy Perry has always excelled at packaging small moments of intimacy; it’s what animates the fleeting moments of post-party panic in hits like “Last Friday Night” and makes “Teenage Dream” one of the best songs of the last decade.

replies.msg: å·²ç¶“ç®—ä¿‚å’äº†

And then there’s “Never Really Over,” which accomplishes maybe what Perry wanted for the whole album: the glistening machinery of a big-budget pop song, calibrated for catharsis.

This is the version of Katy Perry pop can hold space for—one where her packaged self-probing leads somewhere and amounts to something.

This is so fucking sad
In spite of, or maybe because of, her promotional spectacles—Left Shark, the whipped cream bra, teasing her baby’s name with a single release—she’s long been able to comfortably assume legions of people will listen to her music, without even asking themselves why. The unspoken question of Smile is: Why now?

replies.msg:
Historical moment
Fuck....

With 265,000 downloads sold (among its overall first-week total of 300,000, which includes its vinyl and cassette physical versions), BTS's "Dynamite" debuts with the biggest digital sales week since Taylor Swift's "Look What You Made Me Do" in September 2017 (353,000).
UK mid week: Cardi B and Megan Thee Stallion’s "WAP" currently leads race for #1, BLACKPINK and Selena Gomez’ "Ice Cream" is the top debut (#12).
Taylor Swift’s ‘folklore’ is the first and only 2020 album to spend its first five weeks at #1 on the Billboard 200.

Artists with the most wins in VMAs history:

Beyoncé 24
Madonna 20
Lady Gaga18
Troye Sivan’s 'In A Dream EP' debuts at #70 on this week's Billboard 200.
US Certifications (RIAA): Doja Cat, Say So 3x Platinum.

For the first time in Hot 100 history, eight songs debut at #1 in a single calendar year.

Drake - Toosie Slide
Travis Scott & Kid Cudi - THE SCOTTS
Ariana Grande & Justin Bieber - Stuck with U
Lady Gaga & Ariana Grande - Rain On Me
6ix9ine & Nicki Minaj - TROLLZ
Taylor Swift - cardigan
Cardi B & Megan Thee Stallion - WAP
BTS - Dynamite

“Mariah Carey’s Magical Christmas Special” will debut globally exclusively on Apple TV+ this holiday season.

The special is described as an innovative holiday event combining music, dance, and animation featuring Mariah Carey and a star-studded lineup of surprise guests.
